title: Introduction to CLIP - USACH
text:
The incubation program is structured in six sprints in which participants are introduced to a set of conceptual material together with specific strategic workshops. The CLIP has a duration of six months starting from XXX/2023 - XXX / 2024.
Each sprint has specific goals that the CLT should fulfill in order to successfully complete the program. The results of each sprint are to be uploaded to the website assigned to each team. The website will serve as a prototype for the strategic design of the Innovation Labs that the CLT can ultimately use to validate their proposals with other stakeholders, and as a dissemination tool for their local Climate Lab initiative.






The scientific baseline of this program.



The incubation program is conceived as a collective pool of knowledge and therefore brings together various methods, practices and tools shared by consortium members and invited experts. All the different experiences are articulated under the innovation lab framework that has been developed by the ERPI of Université de Lorraine as part of its research strand in fostering collaborative innovation processes (Osorio et al. 2019).


Building on the context analysis and capability mapping, this incubation program proposes to the CLT to proactively and collectively strategize in terms of the main innovation lab components as shown in the figure below.




There are five key action moments throughout the CLIP:

Sprint opening (1h30 per sprint)

Synchronous webinar via Zoom in which sprint goals and main activities are presented to CLT

Online material (Between 1h and 1h30 of video content per sprint)

CLT can access the online material via the CLIP website. Content is composed by conceptual videos, case experiences and complimentary readings
Members of CLT should access this content prior conducting each workshop

Team workshops (Between 1h30 and 2h per workshop)

Each sprint proposes to the CLT a strategic workshop that should be conducted as a team
Workshops templates are provided via the Mural platform

Tutorships (1h30 per sprint)

Intermediary check-ins via Zoom are proposed to the CLT in the forms of Q&A sessions
This is the moment for CLT to exchange with their mentors and guest experts to share their experiences or ask questions regarding the ongoing sprint’s goal.

Upload and share sprint results

By the end of each sprint, the CLT should upload their workshop results to their Climate Lab website prototype
At the beginning of the next sprint, the CLT will briefly present to the consortium their results and learnings








Warning



Participants from each CLT are expected to dedicate 2 hours minimum per week to the CLIP.





To successfully complete the incubation program, the CLT need to: 

Conduct as a team each one of the workshops that will be assigned in each sprint. 
Upload the workshop results to a non-published website that will constitute the prototype for the strategic design of their ClimateLab.
Share progress at the beginning of each sprint.
Final presentation of the strategic design of the Climate Lab at the mid-project meeting.





All the incubation program content will be available through the CLIP Website: <https://lf2l.fr/CLIP/> 
Webinars and video calls will be held through Zoom.
Workshop templates will be available via MURAL.
Website prototype templates will be provided via Google Sites.

title: Introduction to CLIP - USACH
text:
Mentors

Universitat Politècnica de València


Carola Calabuig PhD. Industrial Engineer by the Universitat Politècnica de València (UPV), she is full professor of the Department of Engineering Projects at the UPV and currently Academic Director of the Master’s Degree in Development Cooperation at the UPV, specializing in Project Management and Development Processes. Her main areas of work and interests are framed in development studies and include: development planning; international cooperation; sustainable development and critical approaches; democratic governance; education for development and global citizenship.


Álvaro Fernández-Baldor works at the Center for Development Cooperation of the Polytechnic University of Valencia (UPV - Spain), and is an associate professor in the Department of Engineering Projects of the UPV. He teaches in the Master of Development Cooperation of the UPV. He has done his PhD researching technological projects from the human development and capabilities approach. He also teaches as a guest lecturer in different fields, especially in cooperation masters in the areas related to engineering and development cooperation. He has field experience in Guatemala, Brazil, Peru and Kenya. In 2007 he received the first prize for the best final project in the IV PFC Competition in the field of technology for human development, for a design of an energy supply in an isolated rural area of Guatemala. In 2015 he has been awarded with the Doctoral Thesis Award for Development Cooperation of the Group-9 Universities.


Università di Genova


Dr.-Ing. Paola Alfaro d’Alençon just started in February 2018 as a DFG-Research Fellow associated to the TU-Berlin, Faculty VI, Habitat Unit with the research project for the DFG: Concepts of Co-production and its influence on the development of inclusive spaces – An international comparative study on theories and practices”. She has 15 years of national and international work experience in research, education, knowledge transfer, and urban management and planning. These experiences are based on the topics of sustainable urban development associated with projects on housing (resilient development through interdisciplinary approaches linked to water management and local production chains, as well as through local solutions); governance, and co-production, with network development and stakeholder, cooperation management on urban and regional development strategies related to subjects of climate change, transport and mobility, and urban resilience.


Ashoka


Waldo Soto is a commercial engineer from the Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile with a Diploma in Innovation from Babson College, a Diploma in Global Management from University College London, and a MSc in Urban Management from Technical University Berlin. As Director of 2811, Waldo specialises in social innovation and sustainable urban development.


Gabriela Carrasco is director of 2811 and consultant for Ashoka in Latin America. MPA in Social Innovation and Impact Investment at NYU, Commercial Engineer and Political Scientist at the Catholic University of Chile. Contributing to the solution of the challenges of our region through the articulation of actors and the formation of agents of change.

title: Fundamentals and Principles
text:
3.1 Sprint Opening



Image


Welcome to the first sprint of the CLIP. Here we are going to focus con the Fundamentals and Principles for the Innovation Spaces






Goal of this sprint



The main goal in this sprint is to build your Climate Lab Manifesto

Sprint dates: From April 9 to April 29



A webinar will be held on April 9 to officially launch the incubation program. It will be a synchronous session, so all CLT are expected to attend. In addition, a series of contents and activities are proposed to the CLT to be completed during the sprint:

Firstly, you will find three conceptual videos which are proposed to open the discussion on the three thematic pillars that constitute the Climate Lab project: Climate Change, Social Innovation and Innovation Labs.
Secondly, two case experiences from members of the consortium are shared. This way we can learn a little more about the experience of each of the CLT.
Next, you will find the link to the team workshop of this sprint. The workshop should be completed before the end of the sprint (April 29).
And finally, complementary readings are offered for those who would like to further explore the topics addressed in this sprint.


NOTICE!
The full recording of the webinar can be watched below. Alternatively, you can access the slides from the webinar here.

title: Fundamentals and Principles
text:
3.2 Conceptual Videos

3.2.1 What is Social Innovation? - Gabriela Carrasco


3.2.2 Innovation Spaces - Laure Morel

Professor Laure Morel from Université de Lorraine introduces the notion of innovation spaces and how these collaborative structures can play a major role in fostering social innovation for climate change. This presentation is based on her book chapter “Innovation spaces: new places for collective intelligence?” (Uzunidis et al. 2018).

title: Fundamentals and Principles
text:
3.3 Case Experiences

3.3.1 Universitat Politècnica de València

Professor Carola Calabuig shares her experience and vision on social innovation at the INGENIO Research Institute of the Universitat Politècnica de València. She emphasizes the importance of the collective and grassroots dimension of innovation processes that happen outside the dominant or traditional spaces of knowledge generation.


3.3.2 Universidad de Guadalajara

Professor Javier Garcia of the Universidad de Guadalajara gives an overview of the project Carbon footprint measurement for the generation of sustainable strategies in avocado crops.
